description: Borrowed from French ennui, from Old French enui (“annoyance”), from enuier (modern French ennuyer), from Late Latin inodiō, from Latin in odiō (“hated”). Doublet of annoy.

entries.meaning: A gripping listlessness or melancholia caused by boredom; depression.

verbs.description: ennui (third-person singular simple present ennuis, present participle ennuying, simple past and past participle ennuied or ennuyed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make bored or listless; to weary.
